conclusion: To determine the mass of block B that will allow blocks A and B to remain in equilibrium, analyze the forces acting on both blocks separately.
Inclination of the slope is 30°, and the rope forms a 90° angle on both sides of the pulley.
Identify forces on block A: Weight of block A, \( W_A = mg \), and tension in the rope, \( T \).
Resolve the weight of block A into components: Perpendicular component is \( mg \cos(30^\circ) = mg \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \), parallel component is \( mg \sin(30^\circ) = mg \cdot \frac{1}{2} \).
Since the system is in equilibrium, tension \( T \) must balance the parallel component of weight of block A: \( T = mg \cdot \frac{1}{2} \).
Identify forces on block B: Weight of block B, \( W_B = M_B g \), and tension in the rope, \( T \).
Since the angle of the rope on both sides of the pulley is 90°, the tension \( T \) on both sides of the pulley is equal.
For block B to be in equilibrium, tension \( T \) must balance the weight of block B: \( T = M_B g \).
Set expressions for \( T \) equal: \( mg \cdot \frac{1}{2} = M_B g \).
The mass of block B that will allow blocks A and B to remain stationary is \( \boxed{\frac{m}{2}} \).
